translated: Thousand-character Text in Sanskrit with Preface

Preface to the Thousand-Character Text in Sanskrit: In order to create a model for learning the language for people in the Western countries, each is annotated with the Middle Indian sound below the title.

Chinese characters. For those without characters, the sounds are corrected. These are all essential characters on the road. If one can learn this, then the rest of the language is all understood. It is different from the old thousand-character text. If one also studies the Siddham chapter, then in one or two years of reading Sanskrit texts, one will be able to translate.

Preface to the Old Edition of the Thousand-Character Text in Sanskrit. Preface to the Old Edition of the Thousand-Character Text in Sanskrit. Five General Rules. The precious book has long been hidden in the brocade bag and jade box.
The Thousand-Character Text in Sanskrit is its title.
It was composed by Tripiá¹­aka Master Yijing of the past.
However, in the old texts, only the text is quoted, while the complete book has long been hidden.
In the past, in the Eastern Capital, I occasionally copied a copy, but it was incomplete, remaining from the damaged box and worm-eaten slips.

In recent years, while traveling in Luoyang, I fortunately obtained the original text. In my spare time from meditation, I examined and corrected it, roughly restoring the correct method. The strange teachings from the distant and vast Brahmanic countries were greatly washed away, and the doubts and suspicions in the sacred scriptures were thoroughly eliminated. I alone unfurled my eyebrows in the face of the profound secrets.

However, the author's instructions to people are vast and loving, and I am still meager. Therefore, I forcibly opened my bag and engaged in carving. At that time, in the spring of the dingyou year of the HÅÅ era, on the first day of the first month, the Å›ramaá¹‡a JikmyÅ wrote this in his temporary residence to the east of Luoyang.

General Preface General Preface 1. This book is also known as the Sanskrit-Tang Thousand-Character Text. The Annen Roku records that it was brought back by Master SaichÅ. I have now examined several copies and collated them, but there are still errors. When reading it, gentlemen should fortunately find a good copy and re-examine and correct it.

1. The sounds and rhymes of the Sanskrit-Tang pairs are often not correct. If they cannot be corrected, they should be examined in the various copies, but if there is no basis, they should be left unchanged. Even if there are clear texts in the scriptures, if they are not based on them and this is deleted, the meaning can be understood.

For those who are uncertain about the differences between the various originals, I have occasionally pointed them out and placed them at the beginning. I have also attached the Chinese characters for the sake of young learners.
One is two pieces of palm leaves from the collection of HÅryÅ«ji Temple in Yamato Province.
They are the Heart Sutra of PrajÃ±ÄpÄramitÄ and the UsnÄ«sa Vijaya DhÄraá¹‡Ä«.
At the end, the fourteen sounds of Siddham are written.

The Sanskrit letters here are described based on those palm leaves, but they are often confused with the records of contemporary calligraphers and are difficult to distinguish. They are simply following the world.
For example, in the palm leaves, the second sound of the teeth is written as ô„“¾.
The second sound of the lips is written as ô„—. Since they suddenly show difficulty in following the rules, I do not adopt them. For example, the second sound of the tongue is written as ô„“š.
The second sound of the throat is written as ô„•£.
The fourth is written as ôˆ¡, and the fourth dot in the matra is written as ôˆ¿.
The seventh is written as ô†¿, and the different matra ôˆ€ is written as ôˆ. Although they are different, there is no confusion. The rest are slightly different, but can be seen by looking at them.

The present book is one of them. The four characters in a sentence are allæŠ¼éŸ», but the number of writings and errors are numerous, and the arrangement of characters is chaotic. I have collated several copies, but there is nothing to be ordered, let alone comparing it with Sanskrit. Even if I were to compose a series of rhymes, how could I possibly finalize the languages of the two countries?

Beautiful and ugly, strong and weak.

The Tang-language version of the Thousand-character Classic in Sanskrit is completed. The Sanskrit Thousand-character Classic with Translation Notes is a book in one scroll.
The title says it was compiled by Yijing.
Those who know it are not without doubts.
It was made based on the complete true Tang-Sanskrit characters.
It is named after Master Jing.
However, it has already been of little benefit to beginners.

The flower of the Buddha's teachings, the Dharma, is like a wish-fulfilling jewel, able to fulfill all wishes and desires. It is also like a great rain, able to extinguish the burning afflictions of sentient beings. It is also like a great medicine, able to cure the illnesses of sentient beings. It is also like a great friend, able to protect and benefit sentient beings. It is also like a great boat, able to ferry sentient beings across the ocean of birth and death. It is also like a great lamp, able to illuminate the darkness of ignorance for sentient beings. It is also like a great bridge, able to lead sentient beings to the other shore of nirvÄá¹‡a. It is also like a great path, able to guide sentient beings to the city of nirvÄá¹‡a. It is also like a great vehicle, able to carry sentient beings to the other shore of nirvÄá¹‡a. It is also like a great treasure, able to provide sentient beings with inexhaustible wealth. It is also like a great king, able to protect and benefit sentient beings. It is also like a great mountain, unshakable and unmoved. It is also like a great ocean, able to contain all rivers and streams. It is also like a great cloud, able to rain down the Dharma rain to benefit sentient beings. It is also like a great sun, able to illuminate the darkness of ignorance for sentient beings. It is also like a great moon, able to cool the burning afflictions of sentient beings. It is also like a great wind, able to blow away the afflictions of sentient beings. It is also like a great fire, able to burn away the afflictions of sentient beings. It is also like a great vajra, able to destroy the afflictions of sentient beings. It is also like a great lion, fearless and unhindered. It is also like a great elephant, able to endure all hardships. It is also like a great horse, able to travel to all buddha-lands. It is also like a great medicine, able to cure the illnesses of sentient beings. It is also like a great friend, able to protect and benefit sentient beings. It is also like a great boat, able to ferry sentient beings across the ocean of birth and death. It is also like a great lamp, able to illuminate the darkness of ignorance for sentient beings.
